title: 103_hr2204
content: The Act is named the "Silvio O. Conte Disabilities Prevention Act" and establishes the Silvio O. Conte Disabilities Prevention Program under the Public Health Service Act. The Silvio O. Conte Disabilities Prevention Act authorizes the Secretary to provide grants and contracts for programs aimed at preventing disabilities and secondary conditions. Authorized activities include coordinating prevention efforts, conducting demonstrations, surveillances, studies, public education, and training health professionals. The Secretary establishes priorities for activities under the Silvio O. Conte Disabilities Prevention Act, and financial assistance is provided only if applicants agree to submit required reports and meet necessary application criteria. The Secretary may provide training, technical assistance, and consultations for disability prevention programs. Recipients of financial assistance can request supplies and services instead of funds. The Secretary may provide supplies, equipment, and services to aid recipients in carrying out disability prevention programs. Recipients can request supplies and services instead of funds, and the Secretary will reduce payments to cover the costs incurred. The Secretary can provide supplies, equipment, and services for disability prevention programs. Recipients can request supplies instead of funds, and the Secretary will reduce payments to cover the costs. Evaluations and reports are required, with reports submitted to specific committees and the National Council on Disability. Financial assistance is defined as a grant or contract, and prevention activities address specific issues. The term 'prevention' in the contract refers to activities that address the causes of disabilities, secondary conditions, and functional limitations, aiming to reduce factors that lead to disabilities and increase early identification of problems. Authorization of appropriations is provided for financial assistance under this section. Authorization of appropriations for financial assistance under this section includes $15,000,000 for fiscal year 1994, $20,000,000 for fiscal year 1995, and $25,000,000 for fiscal year 1996, with additional funding as needed for fiscal years 1997 and 1998. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 14, 1993.
